title: Spacer - Comprehensive Usage Examples
description: Complete example configurations for vertical spacing control with responsive heights and multiple unit types (px, rem, em, vh)

examples.name: Small Section Spacer (30px)
examples.description: Tight spacing between related content blocks
examples.visualDescription: 30px vertical gap, subtle breathing room, keeps elements visually connected
examples.useCase: Between paragraphs, list items, minor sections, tightly grouped content

examples.name: Medium Section Spacer (60px)
examples.description: Standard spacing for general content separation
examples.visualDescription: 60px vertical gap, balanced spacing, default content rhythm
examples.useCase: Between content blocks, after headings, standard section gaps, default spacing

examples.name: Large Section Divider (120px)
examples.description: Strong visual separation between major sections
examples.visualDescription: 120px vertical gap, clear section break, emphasizes hierarchy
examples.useCase: Between major sections, before footer, after hero, large content dividers

examples.name: Responsive Spacer (Adaptive Heights)
examples.description: Fully responsive spacing adapting to all device sizes
examples.visualDescription: Desktop: 100px, Tablet: 60px, Mobile: 30px - scales down for smaller screens
examples.useCase: Mobile-first designs, responsive layouts, screen-size-adaptive spacing, consistent vertical rhythm

examples.name: Typography-Relative Spacer (rem Units)
examples.description: Spacing that scales with user font size preferences
examples.visualDescription: 3rem desktop, 2rem tablet, 1.5rem mobile - adapts to user's font size settings
examples.useCase: Accessible designs, typography-based spacing, user font size respect, semantic spacing

remNotes.3rem: 48px if root font is 16px, 60px if user increased to 20px
remNotes.accessibility: Respects user font size preferences (WCAG best practice)
remNotes.whenToUse: Content-heavy sites, blog posts, documentation, accessibility-focused designs

examples.name: Viewport-Relative Spacer (vh Units)
examples.description: Spacing proportional to screen height for full-screen sections
examples.visualDescription: 10vh desktop, 7vh tablet, 5vh mobile - always proportional to viewport height
examples.useCase: Full-screen designs, landing pages, hero sections, scroll-based layouts, parallax designs

vhNotes.dynamicBehavior: Changes when user resizes browser or rotates device
vhNotes.caution: Mobile browsers have vh bugs with URL bar (consider using fixed px on mobile)
vhNotes.whenToUse: Full-screen hero spacing, scroll-based interactions, viewport-dependent layouts

examples.name: Form Field Separator (40px)
examples.description: Spacing between form fields for readability
examples.visualDescription: 40px vertical gap between form inputs, balanced spacing for form flow
examples.useCase: Form layouts, input field spacing, fieldset separators, multi-step forms

formNotes.responsive: Reduce on mobile to avoid excessive scrolling

examples.name: Heading Separator (80px Before, 20px After)
examples.description: Asymmetric spacing for heading visual hierarchy
examples.visualDescription: Large gap before heading (new topic), small gap after (connects to content)
examples.useCase: Before H2/H3 headings, section titles, content hierarchy, topic changes

typographyNotes.pattern: More space before heading than after (3:1 or 4:1 ratio)
typographyNotes.reasoning: Heading belongs to content below, not above
typographyNotes.beforeHeading: Use 60-100px spacer before heading (new section starts)
typographyNotes.afterHeading: Use 15-30px after heading (connects heading to paragraph)
typographyNotes.visualHierarchy: Creates clear content blocks and improves scannability

normal.responsive: Set different px values for md/sm/xs
normal.whenToUse: Precise control, most common use case, predictable spacing
examples: space: {md: 100, sm: 60, xs: 30} - Responsive px values

global.description: Custom unit mode (rem, em, vh, vw, %)
global.units: rem, em, vh, vw, % (any CSS unit)
global.responsive: Set different unit values for md/sm/xs

px.responsive: No automatic scaling - set explicit md/sm/xs values
px.whenToUse: Default choice, precise control, most predictable

rem.description: Root em - relative to root (html) font size
rem.responsive: Scales with user font size preferences
rem.whenToUse: Accessible designs, content sites, respects user preferences
rem.accessibility: WCAG AAA compliance - respects user font size

em.description: Em - relative to parent element font size
em.caution: Can compound in nested elements (avoid deep nesting)

vh.description: Viewport height - percentage of screen height
vh.whenToUse: Full-screen layouts, hero sections, scroll-based designs
vh.caution: Mobile browsers have vh bugs with URL bar - test thoroughly

vw.description: Viewport width - percentage of screen width
vw.whenToUse: Horizontal scrolling, width-relative spacing (rare for vertical spacers)
vw.note: Rarely used for vertical spacing - vh is more common

validationRules.space: Required - Numeric in normal mode, string with unit in global mode
validationRules.space.md: Required - At least desktop value must be set
validationRules.space.sm: Optional - Falls back to md if not set
validationRules.space.xs: Optional - Falls back to sm or md if not set
validationRules.normalMode: space values must be numbers (e.g., 50, not '50px')
validationRules.globalMode: space values must be strings with units (e.g., '3rem', not 3)

warnings: In 'normal' mode, space values are NUMBERS (e.g., 50), not strings ('50px')
In 'global' mode, space values are STRINGS with units (e.g., '3rem', '10vh')
vh units on mobile can be buggy due to URL bar behavior (test on real devices)
Very large spacing (>200px or >15vh) may cause excessive scrolling
Don't use vw for vertical spacers - use vh or px instead
em units compound in nested elements - prefer rem for consistency
Space values without responsive breakpoints (sm/xs) fall back to md
Spacer adds height but no content - won't show up if space: 0 or negative
Multiple spacers in a row add up (2×50px = 100px total spacing)
commonMistakes: Using 'normal' mode with string values: space: {md: '50px'} (should be {md: 50})
Using 'global' mode with number values: space: {md: 3} (should be {md: '3rem'})
Forgetting to set toggle: 'global' when using rem/vh units
Not setting responsive values (sm/xs) for mobile optimization
Using excessive spacing (>150px) on mobile (causes scroll fatigue)
Using em units without understanding parent font size context
Over-using vh on mobile without testing URL bar behavior
Stacking multiple large spacers when one larger spacer would suffice
Using spacer where padding/margin on containers would be more semantic
bestPractices: Use 'normal' mode with px for most cases (simple, predictable)
Use 'global' mode with rem for accessible, content-heavy sites
Set responsive values (md/sm/xs) - reduce spacing 30-50% on mobile
Use 3:1 or 4:1 ratio before/after headings (more space before than after)
For section dividers, use 80-120px on desktop, 40-60px on mobile
Test vh-based spacing on actual mobile devices (not just browser preview)
Prefer rem over px for accessibility (respects user font size)
Don't overuse spacers - consider padding on containers instead
accessibilityNotes: Spacer blocks have no accessibility impact - purely visual spacing
Use rem units to respect user font size preferences (WCAG AAA)
Don't use excessive spacing that requires excessive scrolling
Spacers should not replace semantic HTML structure (use headings, sections)
No ARIA attributes needed - this is layout spacing, not content
Screen readers ignore empty divs - no impact on navigation
Keyboard navigation skips over spacers (no tab stops)
Proper vertical rhythm (spacing) improves readability for all users
performanceConsiderations: Spacer blocks are lightweight - minimal DOM/CSS overhead
Creates single empty div with inline height style
Multiple spacers add minimal DOM nodes
vh units trigger reflow on resize (minimal impact)
rem units are fast - browser calculates once
Hundreds of spacers may bloat HTML slightly (use sparingly)
Consider CSS padding/margin on containers as alternative for fewer DOM nodes

aggressive.description: Strong reduction to minimize mobile scrolling

betweenParagraphs.notes: Subtle breathing room, maintains reading flow

afterHeadings.notes: Small gap connects heading to content below

sectionDividers.notes: Strong visual separation between major sections

heroToContent.notes: Dramatic transition from hero to content

cardGrids.notes: Use between rows in card grids

problemsAndSolutions.solution: Check space value is not 0. Verify toggle mode matches value format (normal=number, global=string).

problemsAndSolutions.problem: Error: 'space: {md: '50px'}' not working in normal mode
problemsAndSolutions.solution: In normal mode, use numbers without units: space: {md: 50}. Or switch to global mode.

problemsAndSolutions.problem: rem spacing not scaling with font size
problemsAndSolutions.solution: Ensure toggle: 'global' is set. Check value is string: space: {md: '3rem'}

problemsAndSolutions.problem: vh spacing jumps on mobile when scrolling
problemsAndSolutions.solution: Mobile browser URL bar affects vh. Use fixed px on mobile: space: {md: '10vh', xs: 80}
Set smaller xs value: space: {md: 100, sm: 60, xs: 30}
Spacers add up - use single larger spacer instead of multiple small ones
Set sm/xs values explicitly: space: {md: 100, sm: 70, xs: 40}
